message: If anybody wants to view it live in my vimrc: http://github.com/oryband/dotvim

OK, I love jellybeans.vim colorscheme, but it has it's flaws. One of them is that it doesn't make the TODO and FIXME strings stand out - It just displays them in the same regular comment color. So, I've searched the www for a way to manually change this within my vimrc, because I also manage all my plugins from there, and thus didn't want to edit jellybeans.vim (If you want to know how, I'm using Vundle plugin manager, based on Pathogen. It's lovely. Use it.) So, I found out that you can create a very simple function to override certain colorscheme attributes (called 'highlights' in vim-speak :), and I'm calling this function whenever `:set colorscheme` is executed. Here's the code:

" Colors
set background=dark
colorscheme jellybeans
"colorscheme desert256
"colorscheme tir_black

function! GlobalColorSettings()  " Set global color settings, regardless of colorscheme currently in use.
    " Set 'TODO' & 'FIXME' strings to be bold and standout as hell.
    highlight Todo term=standout ctermfg=196 ctermbg=226 guifg=#ff4500 guibg=#eeee00

    " Set cursor color to be like in jellybeans.vim colorscheme, but with black text (previously white).
    highlight Cursor ctermfg=Black ctermbg=153 guifg=#000000 guibg=#b0d0f0
endfunction

autocmd ColorScheme * call GlobalColorSettings()  " Call the global color settings on every colorscheme change.
Wow. I needed this exact function about 4 days ago but was too lazy to write it myself. Thanks!

Oh and btw, if anybody wants to override an exact color attribute based from another colorscheme (like i did), just use `:hi` - This will show you all the color attributes for the current colorscheme. Then, just copy the line you want and add it to the function written above.
What did you use it for? (I use it to override the auto-complete menu with contrasting colors, which is good for FuzzyFinder)
I used it to override jellybeans.vim TODO/FIXME and cursor colors. jellybeans.vim doesn't make them stand out. I overrode it using the standout color from desert256.vim.
